user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_AddSubTest:
```c
void UtTest_AddSubTest(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *GroupName,
                       const char *TestName)
{
    char        CompleteTestName[128];
    const char *GroupPtr;
    const char *TestPtr;

    /* Remove any common prefix between the two names.
     * They are often function names that all start with "Test_XXX"
     * and this repetitive information just becomes clutter.
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    TestPtr  = TestName;
    while (*GroupPtr != 0 && *GroupPtr == *TestPtr)
    {
        ++GroupPtr;
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Only break at an underscore(_) to avoid weird effects
     */
    while (TestPtr > TestName && *TestPtr != '_')
    {
        --TestPtr;
    }
    if (*TestPtr == '_')
    {
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Remove a remaining "Test_" prefix on the group name.
     * Again just to remove common repetitive content
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    if (strncmp(GroupPtr, "Test_", 5) == 0)
    {
        GroupPtr += 5;
    }

    (void)snprintf(CompleteTestName, sizeof(CompleteTestName), "%s.%s", GroupPtr, TestPtr);

    UtTest_AddCommon(Test, Setup, Teardown, CompleteTestName, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEST);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in this code. The pointer parameters (Test, Setup, Teardown, GroupName, TestName) are only read and/or passed through; the code does not assign to them. GroupPtr and TestPtr are local pointer variables that are initialized from GroupName/TestName and subsequently incremented/decremented — these are local copies, not the parameter objects themselves. The pointer parameters themselves are never reassigned or altered, and the objects they point to are only read (no modification). Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this function.
